title: 110_s1891
content: IMMUNITY FOR REPORTS OF SUSPECTED TERRORIST ACTIVITY OR SUSPICIOUS BEHAVIOR AND RESPONSE. Immunity is granted to individuals who report suspected terrorist activity or suspicious behavior in good faith and based on reasonable suspicion. They are protected from civil liability under any law for making such reports, unless the report is knowingly false or made recklessly. Authorized officials who respond to covered activity with reasonable and good faith actions also have qualified immunity from civil liability. Authorized officials reporting or responding to suspicious activity are granted qualified immunity from civil liability under relevant laws. Those not entitled to qualified immunity are immune from civil liability if they take reasonable action in good faith. Any person or official immune from liability is entitled to recover attorney fees and costs. In this section, authorized officials involved in security of passenger transportation systems are immune from civil liability and can recover attorney fees and costs. The term "authorized official" includes employees or agents of transportation systems, Department of Homeland Security, Department of Transportation, Department of Justice, and law enforcement officers. The term "covered activity" refers to suspicious activities directed against passenger transportation systems or vehicles. The term "covered activity" refers to suspicious transactions or occurrences involving passenger transportation systems or vehicles indicating potential law violations related to threats to passenger safety, security, or terrorism. Passenger transportation includes public transportation, over-the-road bus transportation, school bus transportation, intercity passenger rail transportation, and passenger vessel transportation. The term "passenger transportation system" refers to entities providing transportation services using vehicles, including infrastructure. The term "vehicle" is defined as per section 1992(16) of title 18, United States Code. This section will take effect immediately upon enactment of the Act.
